questions.question_text: How does Snowflake define its approach to Discretionary Access Control (DAC)?

choices.C: Each object has an owner, who can in turn grant access to that object.
choices.D: Access privileges are assigned to roles, which are in turn assigned to users.
choices.B: An entity to which access can be granted.
choices.A: A defined level of access to an object.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Snowflake defines its approach to Discretionary Access Control (DAC) as follows:

C. Each object has an owner, who can in turn grant access to that object.

This means that each securable object in Snowflake has an owner, and the owner has the ability to grant access to that object to other roles or users

questions.question_text: Which command is used to take away staged files from a Snowflake stage after a successful data ingestion?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/semistructured-considerations
The VARIANT data type imposes a 16 MB size limit on individual rows.

questions.question_text: The Snowflake VARIANT data type imposes a 16 MB size limit on what?
Which Snowflake feature records changes made to a table so actions can be taken using that change data capture?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Access History in Snowflake refers to when the user query reads data and when the SQL statement performs a data write operation, such as INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE along with variations of the COPY command, from the source data object to the target data object. The user access history can be found by querying the Account Usage ACCESS_HISTORY view.

Selected Answer: A
It's A 
"Column lineage
Column lineage (i.e. access history for columns) extends the Account Usage ACCESS_HISTORY view to specify how data flows from the source column to the target column in a write operation. Snowflake tracks the data from the source columns through all subsequent table objects that reference data from the source columns (e.g. INSERT, MERGE, CTAS) provided that objects in the lineage chain are not dropped. Snowflake makes column lineage accessible by enhancing the objects_modified column in the ACCESS_HISTORY view." --> https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/access-history

questions.question_text: Which system-defined, read-only view displays information on column lineage that specifies how data flows from source to target in a SQL write operation?
